text:
I installed Apache using the MSI installer located at 
http://httpd.apache.org/download.cgi.  Once Apache was installed, I attempted 
to view the installed documentation using Internet Explorer 6 and opening the 
index.html file with it.  I was surprised to discover that there was no 
index.html file, but only a language specific index.html.en file.  Of course IE 
6 refused to open the file since it did not have a .html extension.  So I then 
opened the index.html.en file with Netscape.  I was then able to view the index 
page but when I clicked on a link, it attempted to link to another HTML file 
that did not have the .en suffix.  Since that file did not exist (the file had 
a .en suffix when it should not have), the link failed with a 404 error.

Frustrated, I finally gave up on viewing the installed documentation & took a 
look at the online documentation instead.  Unfortunately this was of limited 
use because I could not do a search thru just the installed documentation.  So 
I then attempted to do a straight text search through the installed 
documentation using the Windows 2000 "Search..." dialog...

When I attempted to do a text search in the docs directory for PHP, I ended up 
with a ton of hits, most of which were useless to me.  Because there are 
several copies of the documentation in different languages, as well as a 
boatload of XML files that it appears I don't need to view the docs, I ended up 
with a ton of hits, most of which were on HTML documents in languages that I 
don't know or XML files which I don't care about.  In short, the current 
shipped format of the documentation makes it impossible to do a text search for 
anything.

Today a friend told me that if I viewed the documentation through the Apache 
web server, then these problems would all mysteriously go away (less the 
inability to do a text search).  I can't tell you how frustrating it was not to 
be able to use the documentation.  My issue with viewing the documentation over 
Apache is that I want to be able to view the docs by opening the files directly 
with a browser.  The reason for this is that I do not want to host the Apache 
documentation on my web server.  People that will be visiting my web site have 
no need to view the documentation, and I do not want to make it accessible to 
them.

Wouldn't it be possible to either ship the documentation separately from Apache 
in language specific bundles?  Or wouldn't it be possible to put the docs for 
each language in a separate directory so that one could do a text search on 
just one copy of the docs?  Also, is it necessary to ship the XML files with a 
binary distribution?  The Apache source isn't shipped in the binary 
installation, and near as I can tell, the XML files are only needed to generate 
the documentation, and as an end-user, I really don't want to see them at all.
creator: cdearborn@secluda.com
nd@perlig.de
text:
The distributed documentation is intended to be viewed via webserver and *is*
usable that way.
You may, however, download a language specific CHM file for windows, that may
meet  your needs better, see <http://www.apache.org/dyn/closer.cgi/httpd/docs/>.

The XML files are also distributed by intention, to make it easier for people to
provide patches etc.

Thanks for using Apache.

It is true that the documentation is useable if hosted from the Apache web 
server, however, as I have stated below, I do not want to host the 
documentation on my web server.  It seems to me that this would be a pretty 
common thing for people to want, so I feel that I am not alone in making this 
request.

I also don't think it's unreasonable to want to view/use the HTML documentation 
*without* having to install and configure Apache.

I understand that things are this way by design.  However, I'm trying to make 
the point that the documentation could be much more useable then it currently 
is, and that perhaps in future releases the issues that I've noted could be 
taken into account.

I really don't like the fact that my suggestions appear to be discarded as 
being worthless when I've taken the time to let you folks know about the 
experience that I've had thus far, which has been extremely frustrating.

At the least, it should be documented somewhere in big, red, bold letters that 
the HTML documentation can only be viewed when served thru the Apache web 
server.

<http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/>.

> I really don't like the fact that my suggestions appear to be discarded as 
> being worthless when I've taken the time to let you folks know about the 
> experience that I've had thus far, which has been extremely frustrating.

What the heck do you think we're doing here? You're considering your special
situation as a "major bug", which is definitely not. Your report is therefore
invalid.
Did you really read my posting? Did you, for example, try a CHM file? I must
miss something in your reply.

However, just FYI: the main point of your suggestions (providing download
packages) were already discussed some time ago on the docs list - and voted down
(mostly because of conceptual problems like incomplete translations). We provide
currently only special formats like CHM and PDF (in development).

We may reconsider, however, and you are welcome to provide help within the
documentation project.

> At the least, it should be documented somewhere in big, red, bold letters that 
> the HTML documentation can only be viewed when served thru the Apache web 
> server.

As already said - that is not true.

Last Note: If it sounds a bit harsh, don't care too much, I'm absolutely
interested in a serious discussion.

I'm glad we can discuss this using this mechanism.  This is the first time I've 
ever used this system & I didn't realize that it worked in this way.

>> At the least, it should be documented somewhere in big, red, bold letters 
that 
>> the HTML documentation can only be viewed when served thru the Apache web 
>> server.

> As already said - that is not true.

Can you explain to me how I can view the installed HTML documentation without 
serving it thru the Apache web server?  As far as I can see there's no way to 
do that.

text:
> As already said - that is not true.

>> Can you explain to me how I can view the installed HTML documentation without 
>> serving it thru the Apache web server?  As far as I can see there's no way to 
>> do that.

André meant that there are valuable alternatives, e.g. the CHM files and
hopefully in the near future also PDF files. Another alternative which is always
up-to-date and very well-connected is http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/

You mentioned that you tried the Windows search dialog; did you also try to
search only for *.html.en files which contain the searched term? Isn't this
possible with Windows?

Hmmm, I really don't see a point in reporting this as a major bug. Perhaps an
enhancement but not a bug.

> André meant that there are valuable alternatives, e.g. the CHM files and
> hopefully in the near future also PDF files. Another alternative which is 
always
> up-to-date and very well-connected is http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/

Gotcha.

> You mentioned that you tried the Windows search dialog; did you also try to
> search only for *.html.en files which contain the searched term? Isn't this
> possible with Windows?

It certainly is.  Once I realized that linking from one doc to the other 
wouldn't work though, I gave up on the installed docs.  I guess I could have 
done the text search on my local system, then hunted down the file in the 
online docs...

> Hmmm, I really don't see a point in reporting this as a major bug. Perhaps an
> enhancement but not a bug.

Feel free to call it whatever you would like!

I still think it should be documented in big glowing red letters somewhere in a 
very obvious place that the installed HTML documentation is only viewable when 
served thru the Apache web server.  Such a sentence would have saved me a 
tremendous amount of frustration.
creator: cdearborn@secluda.com

text:
Unfortunately, if we placed every hint that ever cost someone an hour of
frustration in big glowing red letters in the front of the docs, the front page
would be 1000 pages of big glowing red letters.

Now, if you could suggest where exactly we should place this so
that it would be obvious but wouldn't confuse or distract the 99% of people
who don't run into this problem, that would be great.

[Writing documentation is easy; writing well structured, clear documentation
is hard.]
